Award.AwardTitle: RUI: The Impact of Multiple Functional Roles on the Morphological Diversification of Turtle Shells
Award.AbstractNarration:
Since most parts of organisms perform multiple functions, to understand how conflicting functional demands can affect those parts, evolution is critical; however, neither a theoretical framework nor extensive real-world data are available to address this topic. To address this gap, this study will integrate detailed anatomical and engineering analyses (including computer modeling and real-world validation using models) of the shells of all 300 living species of turtle. Three functional attributes will be considered: shell strength, shell drag during swimming, and shell stability when the turtle is overturned. The data will be used to address three questions. Do shells that must perform more functions evolve differently than those with fewer functions (e.g., do aquatic turtle shells evolve differently than those of land turtles, which don't need to be efficient underwater?). Are there shells that perform poorly for any of their functions? If different functions impose different requirements on shells (e.g., flat shells seem best for swimming, but worse for strength), how do shells compromise among functions during evolution?

This study will address several recent Grand Challenges in Organismal Biology, helping scientists to understand how organisms interact with their environment during evolution and integrating the analysis of biological structures with advanced engineering techniques. All data will be made publicly available via the Dryad (www.datadryad.org) and Biomesh (www.biomesh.org) databases. The results will be applicable to other biological shells (e.g., eggs or skulls) or to the development of artificial structures such as small submersibles. This project has an extensive educational component. Twenty to twenty-five undergraduate students will work on this project, receiving applied training in cutting-edge imaging and analysis techniques (skills applicable in careers from medicine to engineering) and experience with scientific research. Students will also develop public communication skills when they help develop and present biology lessons with the PI at local primary schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
I and 11 undergraduate students used turtle shells as a model system to explore hypotheses about the effect of multiple functional roles on evolutionary variability within biological structures.  Most biological structures perform multiple tasks - for example, birds use their beaks to obtain food and to build nests - and these tasks affect how the structures evolve.  However, it is unclear how performing multiple functions affects how much these structures can diversify or evolve into a variety of different shapes among species.  Biologists typically assume that performing multiple functions inhibits diversification - structures are constrained to shapes that perform adequately for all functions, even if certain shapes outside of that range would be better for individual functions.  However, recently researchers have explored the possibility that performing multiple functions promotes diversification - that structures with multiple functions will evolve a range of different shapes which emphasize varying degrees of importance for different functions.  Understanding these patterns is important for interpreting and understanding large-scale patterns of evolution and understanding how evolution can optimize performance across multiple functions.  Given that most biological structures are involved in multiple functions, this work thus provides insights into the processes that have led to the great diversity of life on this planet.

Turtle shells, with their rigid structure, simple shapes, and clear functional roles, are ideal for these questions.  My students and I traveled to museums across the US and collected data from 2722 turtle specimens, spanning 274 species (from ~300 hard-shelled turtle species) both aquatic and terrestrial.  All these species use the shell as protection, and all must overcome the restrictions of the shell in order to turn right side up if they are flipped over (even the aquatic species travel over land to find new habitats or lay eggs).  However, the aquatic species also experience drag from their shell when swimming.  Thus aquatic turtle shells are involved in one more functional role (hydrodynamics) than terrestrial shells, allowing tests on how additional roles affect evolutionary variation.

We used the shell shape data, along with a phylogeny (a "family tree" of the species), to test whether aquatic or terrestrial turtle shells were more diverse.  Terrestrial species showed more variation in shell shape, supporting the traditional view that additional functional demands constrain the potential range of shapes that can evolve among species.  Notably, this is not because terrestrial turtles were evolving faster that aquatic species - in fact, the aquatic species were evolving faster -but because the range of shapes that they evolved among were less restricted.  

Next we explored the role of functional performance in explaining variation in shell shape.  We used engineering methods to predict shell strength, and then validated these models by crushing actual (dead) turtle shells in Bucknell's engineering department.  The engineering models predicted shell strength and breaking behavior quite well.  We also assessed hydrodynamics by printing 3D models of turtle shells and measuring drag on those shells directly.  These tests, along with previous knowledge of how shell shape affects self-righting ability, showed that we could successfully assess performance on a wide variety of shell shapes - not just those which had evolved and were seen in actual turtles, but also possible shell shapes that had never evolved.  We refined methods (previously developed by me and collaborators) for combining form-function relationships to predict patterns of evolutionary variation, and applied those to our current turtle data set.  We found that the three functions under consideration predicted the distribution of actual shell shapes with striking precision, explaining why certain otherwise reasonable-looking shell shapes never evolved and outperforming traditional methods for finding "optimal" shapes.  Thus we have not only established a firm connection between functional performance and turtle shell shape variation, but have also provided powerful new methods for analyzing optimal combinations of functions in other structures. 

All data and results from this study, including the shell shape data, the family tree, CT scans of 5 turtle species, and hydrodynamic data on 23 shell shapes, is available to the public.  11 undergraduates were trained in all aspects of the scientific process, from hypothesis generation to presenting their results.  Nearly all traveled to national meetings to present their work.  6 of these students conducted their own projects on subsets of the data and generated first-authored publications on their work; 4 of these are already published and 2 are in review.  6 of these students are now in graduate programs (academic and pre-health). This project resulted in 9 manuscripts, 6 already published, and 17 conference presentations.  It also produced powerful new methods for analyzing functional data.  We also traveled to local elementary schools and other local venues to give "turtle talks" on turtle conservation, biology, and how to think like a scientist (for example, being willing to change your mind if you get a result you didn't expect).
